Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 1, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
There are more than one and a half billion
people out there using the internet every day, and just like you, they're looking for
answers. We here at SciShow are looking for answers
too, answers to questions about science and nature and the human body, Earth and the universe! So we're working with Google and YouTube to
answer ten of the most popular questions searched for on the internet. This is the World's Most Asked Questions! [Intro] Today’s question is: How can I get rid of
hiccups? People have all kinds of hiccup remedies that
they swear by, none of which seem to have much to do with each other -- like, swallowing
a teaspoon of sugar, or guzzling a glass of water, or just holding your breath. But to figure out how to get rid of hiccups
-- and why we get them in the first place -- you gotta start with getting to know your
diaphragm. The diaphragm is a sheet of muscle under your
lungs that is one of the most important muscles you have, if you enjoy things like breathing. And a hiccup is just an involuntary spasm
of the diaphragm that causes it to contract suddenly. When that happens, you take in a gulp of air
really quickly, until your vocal folds -- the membranes at the top of your throat -- clamp
shut. That’s what causes the “hic” sound. Most of the time, the spasm stops as quickly
as it started, and you can just say “excuse me” and get on with your life. But sometimes, those spasms won’t stop ... which
means it’s time to get your diaphragm to relax. To do this, you basically gotta hit the reset
button on your nervous system -- or at least the part that controls your diaphragm. You can do that in a couple of different ways. One is to stimulate your vagus nerve -- that's
a nerve that runs down your neck from the base of your brain, and it regulates some
of your body’s most important functions, including your heartbeat and your breathing. Basically, you need to stimulate this nerve
-- distract it, if you will -- so it’ll stop constantly zapping your diaphragm. So, some people have luck getting rid of hiccups
by swallowing a teaspoon of sugar. Sounds delicious, but it’s harder than it
sounds. The act of gulping down those dry granules
can provide just enough confusing stimulus for your vagus nerve to start focusing on
your throat, and leave your diaphragm alone. Another more common approach to kicking the
hiccups is to increase the level of carbon dioxide in your bloodstream. That might seem a little weird, but your natural
breathing rhythms are regulated by your CO2 levels, and if they get too high, your nervous
system will signal your diaphragm and lungs to make sure they’re doing their job. And this is what’s behind most of the hiccup-busting
techniques you’ve probably heard of -- like holding your breath, or breathing into a paper
bag, or drinking a tall glass of water. All of that stuff stops your intake of oxygen
and ramps up your internal CO2 concentration, which signals your diaphragm to get its head
in the game and fix things. If the human body weren't so weird, it wouldn't
be so fascinating. And speaking of hiccup cures, of those of
you who filled out our SciShow Survey, 54% said that holding your breath was your preferred
method for relieving hiccups, while at a close second was drinking water, at 37%. We're loving answering these questions, but
of all the questions in the world, what do YOU most want answered? Let us know on Facebook or Twitter or in the
comments down below, and we will answer the best questions in a new video at the end of
the month. Don’t forget to use the hashtag #WMAQ, for
World's Most Asked Questions, and stay tuned for more answers here on SciShow.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Why do we hiccup?
Options: A. Our diaphragm causes our vocal folds to involuntarily spasm causing a hiccup., B. Our lungs involuntarily spasm and cause the diaphragm to clamp down., C. Our diaphragm has an involuntary spasm which causes us to take in a sudden gulp of air and our vocal folds clamp shut., D. Our vocal folds involuntarily spasm and cause our lungs to seize and our diaphragm to clamp down.
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the primary cause of hiccups? Options: A. An involuntary spasm of the diaphragm, B. Swallowing a teaspoon of sugar, C. Drinking a tall glass of water, D. Holding your breath Correct Option: A
Question 2: Which muscle under the lungs is responsible for controlling breathing and is often involved in hiccups? Options: A. Lungs, B. Heart, C. Diaphragm, D. Vocal folds Correct Option: C
Question 3: What is the main function of the vagus nerve in relation to hiccups? Options: A. To regulate heart rate, B. To control breathing, C. To regulate the diaphragm contractions and breathing patterns, D. To regulate digestion Correct Option: C
Question 4: What is a common approach to getting rid of hiccups by increasing the level of carbon dioxide in the bloodstream? Options: A. Drinking a glass of water, B. Holding your breath, C. Breathing into a paper bag, D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 5: According to the SciShow Survey, what percentage of people preferred holding their breath to relieve hiccups? Options: A. 20%, B. 37%, C. 54%, D. 67% Correct Option: C
Question 6: What is the role of the vocal folds in producing the "hic" sound during a hiccup? Options: A. To block airflow, B. To amplify sound, C. To clamp shut when the diaphragm contracts suddenly, D. To regulate breathing Correct Option: C
Question 7: Why do hiccups sometimes stop on their own, but other times require intervention? Options: A. Because of the diaphragm's natural contractions, B. Because of the vagus nerve's constant stimulation, C. Because the body needs to reset its nervous system, D. Because of the body's natural reflexes to regulate breathing Correct Option: C
Question 8: What is the effect of gulping down dry granules of sugar on the vagus nerve? Options: A. It causes the vagus nerve to focus on the diaphragm, B. It causes the vagus nerve to focus on the throat, C. It has no effect on the vagus nerve, D. It causes the vagus nerve to contract Correct Option: B
Question 9: What is the primary function of the body's natural breathing rhythms? Options: A. To regulate heart rate, B. To regulate digestion, C. To regulate the level of carbon dioxide in the bloodstream, D. To regulate body temperature Correct Option: C
Question 10: According to the SciShow Survey, what is the second most popular method for relieving hiccups among those who filled out the survey? Options: A. Holding your breath, B. Drinking a glass of water, C. Swallowing a teaspoon of sugar, D. Breathing into a paper bag Correct Option: B
Question 11: What is the relationship between the level of carbon dioxide in the bloodstream and the body's breathing rhythms? Options: A. It has no effect on breathing rhythms, B. It decreases the level of breathing, C. It increases the level of breathing, D. It regulates the level of breathing Correct Option: D
Question 12: What percentage of people, according to the SciShow Survey, said that drinking water was their preferred method for relieving hiccups? Options: A. 20%, B. 37%, C. 54%, D. 67% Correct Option: B
Question 13: What is the role of the diaphragm in breathing and hiccups? Options: A. To block airflow, B. To amplify sound, C. To contract suddenly and cause hiccups, D. To regulate breathing Correct Option: C
Question 14: Why is it difficult to swallow a teaspoon of sugar? Options: A. Because it is too hot, B. Because it is too cold, C. Because it is dry and hard to swallow, D. Because it is too large Correct Option: C
Question 15: What is the relationship between the vagus nerve and the diaphragm? Options: A. The vagus nerve controls the diaphragm, B. The vagus nerve is controlled by the diaphragm, C. The vagus nerve regulates the diaphragm's contractions, D. The vagus nerve has no effect on the diaphragm Correct Option: C
Question 16: What is the effect of drinking a glass of water on the level of carbon dioxide in the bloodstream? Options: A. It decreases the level of carbon dioxide, B. It increases the level of carbon dioxide, C. It has no effect on the level of carbon dioxide, D. It regulates the level of carbon dioxide Correct Option: B
Question 17: According to the SciShow Survey, what percentage of people said that they had tried holding their breath to relieve hiccups? Options: A. 20%, B. 37%, C. 54%, D. 67% Correct Option: C
Question 18: What is the relationship between the level of carbon dioxide in the bloodstream and the body's natural breathing rhythms? Options: A. It has no effect on breathing rhythms, B. It decreases the level of breathing, C. It increases the level of breathing, D. It regulates the level of breathing Correct Option: D
Question 19: What is the role of the vocal folds in producing the "hic" sound during a hiccup? Options: A. To block airflow, B. To amplify sound, C. To clamp shut when the diaphragm contracts suddenly, D. To regulate breathing Correct Option: C
Question 20: Why do people often try to hold their breath to relieve hiccups? Options: A. Because it is a natural reflex, B. Because it is a common remedy, C. Because it increases the level of carbon dioxide in the bloodstream, D. Because it has no effect on the diaphragm Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 1: What is the primary cause of hiccups? 

However, an even more similar question is Question 13: What is the role of the diaphragm in breathing and hiccups? 

But the most similar question is actually Question 3 in some aspects but not in others, however Question 6 and Question 19, and Question 1 and Question 13 have parts of the Ground Truth MCQ. 

However if I had to choose one it would be Question 13: What is the role of the diaphragm in breathing and hiccups?

So the index is: 13

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 1, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
There are more than one and a half billion
people out there using the internet every day, and just like you, they're looking for
answers. We here at SciShow are looking for answers
too, answers to questions about science and nature and the human body, Earth and the universe! So we're working with Google and YouTube to
answer ten of the most popular questions searched for on the internet. This is the World's Most Asked Questions! [Intro] Today’s question is: How can I get rid of
hiccups? People have all kinds of hiccup remedies that
they swear by, none of which seem to have much to do with each other -- like, swallowing
a teaspoon of sugar, or guzzling a glass of water, or just holding your breath. But to figure out how to get rid of hiccups
-- and why we get them in the first place -- you gotta start with getting to know your
diaphragm. The diaphragm is a sheet of muscle under your
lungs that is one of the most important muscles you have, if you enjoy things like breathing. And a hiccup is just an involuntary spasm
of the diaphragm that causes it to contract suddenly. When that happens, you take in a gulp of air
really quickly, until your vocal folds -- the membranes at the top of your throat -- clamp
shut. That’s what causes the “hic” sound. Most of the time, the spasm stops as quickly
as it started, and you can just say “excuse me” and get on with your life. But sometimes, those spasms won’t stop ... which
means it’s time to get your diaphragm to relax. To do this, you basically gotta hit the reset
button on your nervous system -- or at least the part that controls your diaphragm. You can do that in a couple of different ways. One is to stimulate your vagus nerve -- that's
a nerve that runs down your neck from the base of your brain, and it regulates some
of your body’s most important functions, including your heartbeat and your breathing. Basically, you need to stimulate this nerve
-- distract it, if you will -- so it’ll stop constantly zapping your diaphragm. So, some people have luck getting rid of hiccups
by swallowing a teaspoon of sugar. Sounds delicious, but it’s harder than it
sounds. The act of gulping down those dry granules
can provide just enough confusing stimulus for your vagus nerve to start focusing on
your throat, and leave your diaphragm alone. Another more common approach to kicking the
hiccups is to increase the level of carbon dioxide in your bloodstream. That might seem a little weird, but your natural
breathing rhythms are regulated by your CO2 levels, and if they get too high, your nervous
system will signal your diaphragm and lungs to make sure they’re doing their job. And this is what’s behind most of the hiccup-busting
techniques you’ve probably heard of -- like holding your breath, or breathing into a paper
bag, or drinking a tall glass of water. All of that stuff stops your intake of oxygen
and ramps up your internal CO2 concentration, which signals your diaphragm to get its head
in the game and fix things. If the human body weren't so weird, it wouldn't
be so fascinating. And speaking of hiccup cures, of those of
you who filled out our SciShow Survey, 54% said that holding your breath was your preferred
method for relieving hiccups, while at a close second was drinking water, at 37%. We're loving answering these questions, but
of all the questions in the world, what do YOU most want answered? Let us know on Facebook or Twitter or in the
comments down below, and we will answer the best questions in a new video at the end of
the month. Don’t forget to use the hashtag #WMAQ, for
World's Most Asked Questions, and stay tuned for more answers here on SciShow.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What is a diaphragm?
Options: A. A small muscle in between your lungs that is one of the most important muscles for breathing., B. A sac of air pockets that live inside your lung and are most important for breathing., C. A nerve that runs from the base of your skull down your spine and is important for breathing., D. A sheet of muscle underneath your lungs that is one of the most important muscles for breathing.
Correct Option: D

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 1, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
There are more than one and a half billion
people out there using the internet every day, and just like you, they're looking for
answers. We here at SciShow are looking for answers
too, answers to questions about science and nature and the human body, Earth and the universe! So we're working with Google and YouTube to
answer ten of the most popular questions searched for on the internet. This is the World's Most Asked Questions! [Intro] Today’s question is: How can I get rid of
hiccups? People have all kinds of hiccup remedies that
they swear by, none of which seem to have much to do with each other -- like, swallowing
a teaspoon of sugar, or guzzling a glass of water, or just holding your breath. But to figure out how to get rid of hiccups
-- and why we get them in the first place -- you gotta start with getting to know your
diaphragm. The diaphragm is a sheet of muscle under your
lungs that is one of the most important muscles you have, if you enjoy things like breathing. And a hiccup is just an involuntary spasm
of the diaphragm that causes it to contract suddenly. When that happens, you take in a gulp of air
really quickly, until your vocal folds -- the membranes at the top of your throat -- clamp
shut. That’s what causes the “hic” sound. Most of the time, the spasm stops as quickly
as it started, and you can just say “excuse me” and get on with your life. But sometimes, those spasms won’t stop ... which
means it’s time to get your diaphragm to relax. To do this, you basically gotta hit the reset
button on your nervous system -- or at least the part that controls your diaphragm. You can do that in a couple of different ways. One is to stimulate your vagus nerve -- that's
a nerve that runs down your neck from the base of your brain, and it regulates some
of your body’s most important functions, including your heartbeat and your breathing. Basically, you need to stimulate this nerve
-- distract it, if you will -- so it’ll stop constantly zapping your diaphragm. So, some people have luck getting rid of hiccups
by swallowing a teaspoon of sugar. Sounds delicious, but it’s harder than it
sounds. The act of gulping down those dry granules
can provide just enough confusing stimulus for your vagus nerve to start focusing on
your throat, and leave your diaphragm alone. Another more common approach to kicking the
hiccups is to increase the level of carbon dioxide in your bloodstream. That might seem a little weird, but your natural
breathing rhythms are regulated by your CO2 levels, and if they get too high, your nervous
system will signal your diaphragm and lungs to make sure they’re doing their job. And this is what’s behind most of the hiccup-busting
techniques you’ve probably heard of -- like holding your breath, or breathing into a paper
bag, or drinking a tall glass of water. All of that stuff stops your intake of oxygen
and ramps up your internal CO2 concentration, which signals your diaphragm to get its head
in the game and fix things. If the human body weren't so weird, it wouldn't
be so fascinating. And speaking of hiccup cures, of those of
you who filled out our SciShow Survey, 54% said that holding your breath was your preferred
method for relieving hiccups, while at a close second was drinking water, at 37%. We're loving answering these questions, but
of all the questions in the world, what do YOU most want answered? Let us know on Facebook or Twitter or in the
comments down below, and we will answer the best questions in a new video at the end of
the month. Don’t forget to use the hashtag #WMAQ, for
World's Most Asked Questions, and stay tuned for more answers here on SciShow.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: How do we stop hiccups?
Options: A. We have to tell our diaphragm to stop hiccupping., B. We have to hit the reset button on our nervous system and get our diaphragm to relax., C. We have to stimulate our diaphragm more to make it change the hiccups., D. We can't stop hiccups, they stop themselves.
Correct Option: B

Matching Response:

**Question 7: Why do hiccups sometimes stop on their own, but other times require intervention? Options: A. Because of the diaphragm's natural contractions, B. Because of the vagus nerve's constant stimulation, C. Because the body needs to reset its nervous system, D. Because of the body's natural reflexes to regulate breathing Correct Option: C**

If I were to modify the generated MCQs to create a better match, I would suggest rephrasing **Question 7** to directly ask about stopping hiccups and revising the options to better align with the ground truth MCQ.

**Modified Question 7: How do we stop hiccups? Options: A. We have to stimulate our diaphragm more, B. We have to hit the reset button on our nervous system and get our diaphragm to relax, C. We have to regulate our breathing patterns, D. We can't stop hiccups, they stop themselves Correct Option: B**

This modified question would be a better match for the ground truth MCQ. However, since I am limited to selecting from the original generated MCQs, I will stick with **Question 7** as the most similar, despite its limitations.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 1, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
There are more than one and a half billion
people out there using the internet every day, and just like you, they're looking for
answers. We here at SciShow are looking for answers
too, answers to questions about science and nature and the human body, Earth and the universe! So we're working with Google and YouTube to
answer ten of the most popular questions searched for on the internet. This is the World's Most Asked Questions! [Intro] Today’s question is: How can I get rid of
hiccups? People have all kinds of hiccup remedies that
they swear by, none of which seem to have much to do with each other -- like, swallowing
a teaspoon of sugar, or guzzling a glass of water, or just holding your breath. But to figure out how to get rid of hiccups
-- and why we get them in the first place -- you gotta start with getting to know your
diaphragm. The diaphragm is a sheet of muscle under your
lungs that is one of the most important muscles you have, if you enjoy things like breathing. And a hiccup is just an involuntary spasm
of the diaphragm that causes it to contract suddenly. When that happens, you take in a gulp of air
really quickly, until your vocal folds -- the membranes at the top of your throat -- clamp
shut. That’s what causes the “hic” sound. Most of the time, the spasm stops as quickly
as it started, and you can just say “excuse me” and get on with your life. But sometimes, those spasms won’t stop ... which
means it’s time to get your diaphragm to relax. To do this, you basically gotta hit the reset
button on your nervous system -- or at least the part that controls your diaphragm. You can do that in a couple of different ways. One is to stimulate your vagus nerve -- that's
a nerve that runs down your neck from the base of your brain, and it regulates some
of your body’s most important functions, including your heartbeat and your breathing. Basically, you need to stimulate this nerve
-- distract it, if you will -- so it’ll stop constantly zapping your diaphragm. So, some people have luck getting rid of hiccups
by swallowing a teaspoon of sugar. Sounds delicious, but it’s harder than it
sounds. The act of gulping down those dry granules
can provide just enough confusing stimulus for your vagus nerve to start focusing on
your throat, and leave your diaphragm alone. Another more common approach to kicking the
hiccups is to increase the level of carbon dioxide in your bloodstream. That might seem a little weird, but your natural
breathing rhythms are regulated by your CO2 levels, and if they get too high, your nervous
system will signal your diaphragm and lungs to make sure they’re doing their job. And this is what’s behind most of the hiccup-busting
techniques you’ve probably heard of -- like holding your breath, or breathing into a paper
bag, or drinking a tall glass of water. All of that stuff stops your intake of oxygen
and ramps up your internal CO2 concentration, which signals your diaphragm to get its head
in the game and fix things. If the human body weren't so weird, it wouldn't
be so fascinating. And speaking of hiccup cures, of those of
you who filled out our SciShow Survey, 54% said that holding your breath was your preferred
method for relieving hiccups, while at a close second was drinking water, at 37%. We're loving answering these questions, but
of all the questions in the world, what do YOU most want answered? Let us know on Facebook or Twitter or in the
comments down below, and we will answer the best questions in a new video at the end of
the month. Don’t forget to use the hashtag #WMAQ, for
World's Most Asked Questions, and stay tuned for more answers here on SciShow.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: How does swallowing a spoonful of sugar help stop hiccups?
Options: A. Swallowing sugar is hard. It confuses the Vagus Nerve and makes it start concentrating on your throat swallowing which leave the diaphragm alone., B. Swallowing sugar is too sweet. It refocuses the Vagus Nerve on the incredible sweetness which leaves the diaphragm alone., C. Swallowing sugar stimulates your vocal folds and causes them to relax., D. Swallowing sugar causes your body to inhale a large amount of oxygen which calms your diaphragm.
Correct Option: A

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the primary cause of hiccups? Options: A. An involuntary spasm of the diaphragm, B. Swallowing a teaspoon of sugar, C. Drinking a tall glass of water, D. Holding your breath Correct Option: A
Question 2: Which muscle under the lungs is responsible for controlling breathing and is often involved in hiccups? Options: A. Lungs, B. Heart, C. Diaphragm, D. Vocal folds Correct Option: C
Question 3: What is the main function of the vagus nerve in relation to hiccups? Options: A. To regulate heart rate, B. To control breathing, C. To regulate the diaphragm contractions and breathing patterns, D. To regulate digestion Correct Option: C
Question 4: What is a common approach to getting rid of hiccups by increasing the level of carbon dioxide in the bloodstream? Options: A. Drinking a glass of water, B. Holding your breath, C. Breathing into a paper bag, D. All of the above Correct Option: D
Question 5: According to the SciShow Survey, what percentage of people preferred holding their breath to relieve hiccups? Options: A. 20%, B. 37%, C. 54%, D. 67% Correct Option: C
Question 6: What is the role of the vocal folds in producing the "hic" sound during a hiccup? Options: A. To block airflow, B. To amplify sound, C. To clamp shut when the diaphragm contracts suddenly, D. To regulate breathing Correct Option: C
Question 7: Why do hiccups sometimes stop on their own, but other times require intervention? Options: A. Because of the diaphragm's natural contractions, B. Because of the vagus nerve's constant stimulation, C. Because the body needs to reset its nervous system, D. Because of the body's natural reflexes to regulate breathing Correct Option: C
Question 8: What is the effect of gulping down dry granules of sugar on the vagus nerve? Options: A. It causes the vagus nerve to focus on the diaphragm, B. It causes the vagus nerve to focus on the throat, C. It has no effect on the vagus nerve, D. It causes the vagus nerve to contract Correct Option: B
Question 9: What is the primary function of the body's natural breathing rhythms? Options: A. To regulate heart rate, B. To regulate digestion, C. To regulate the level of carbon dioxide in the bloodstream, D. To regulate body temperature Correct Option: C
Question 10: According to the SciShow Survey, what is the second most popular method for relieving hiccups among those who filled out the survey? Options: A. Holding your breath, B. Drinking a glass of water, C. Swallowing a teaspoon of sugar, D. Breathing into a paper bag Correct Option: B
Question 11: What is the relationship between the level of carbon dioxide in the bloodstream and the body's breathing rhythms? Options: A. It has no effect on breathing rhythms, B. It decreases the level of breathing, C. It increases the level of breathing, D. It regulates the level of breathing Correct Option: D
Question 12: What percentage of people, according to the SciShow Survey, said that drinking water was their preferred method for relieving hiccups? Options: A. 20%, B. 37%, C. 54%, D. 67% Correct Option: B
Question 13: What is the role of the diaphragm in breathing and hiccups? Options: A. To block airflow, B. To amplify sound, C. To contract suddenly and cause hiccups, D. To regulate breathing Correct Option: C
Question 14: Why is it difficult to swallow a teaspoon of sugar? Options: A. Because it is too hot, B. Because it is too cold, C. Because it is dry and hard to swallow, D. Because it is too large Correct Option: C
Question 15: What is the relationship between the vagus nerve and the diaphragm? Options: A. The vagus nerve controls the diaphragm, B. The vagus nerve is controlled by the diaphragm, C. The vagus nerve regulates the diaphragm's contractions, D. The vagus nerve has no effect on the diaphragm Correct Option: C
Question 16: What is the effect of drinking a glass of water on the level of carbon dioxide in the bloodstream? Options: A. It decreases the level of carbon dioxide, B. It increases the level of carbon dioxide, C. It has no effect on the level of carbon dioxide, D. It regulates the level of carbon dioxide Correct Option: B
Question 17: According to the SciShow Survey, what percentage of people said that they had tried holding their breath to relieve hiccups? Options: A. 20%, B. 37%, C. 54%, D. 67% Correct Option: C
Question 18: What is the relationship between the level of carbon dioxide in the bloodstream and the body's natural breathing rhythms? Options: A. It has no effect on breathing rhythms, B. It decreases the level of breathing, C. It increases the level of breathing, D. It regulates the level of breathing Correct Option: D
Question 19: What is the role of the vocal folds in producing the "hic" sound during a hiccup? Options: A. To block airflow, B. To amplify sound, C. To clamp shut when the diaphragm contracts suddenly, D. To regulate breathing Correct Option: C
Question 20: Why do people often try to hold their breath to relieve hiccups? Options: A. Because it is a natural reflex, B. Because it is a common remedy, C. Because it increases the level of carbon dioxide in the bloodstream, D. Because it has no effect on the diaphragm Correct Option: C


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 8: What is the effect of gulping down dry granules of sugar on the vagus nerve?

This question matches the ground truth MCQ in terms of question intent, options, and content. Both questions are asking about the effect of swallowing sugar on the vagus nerve and how it helps to stop hiccups. The correct option in both questions is that swallowing sugar distracts the vagus nerve, causing it to focus on the throat and leave the diaphragm alone.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 8

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 2, Question 1

**Transcript**:
[Music] Hey there, engineer buddies! I just want to thank you so much
for helping out in the last episode. I needed to get my phone out of the storm
drain, and together, we designed a solution. Our robot was just one of many possible solutions, and maybe you had an even better idea at home. If you did, please send it my way.
I'd love to check it out! But I've got a whole new challenge for you. Have you ever just wanted
some space to yourself? A place to relax, do your own thing,
eat Nutella straight off your fingers, and burp with abandon? Yeah, I need that.
That is a thing I need. You know what can help? I bet you already guessed it! Engineering. So how do we use the engineering
process to solve this problem? [Music] Well, first, we've got to define the problem. I need a place that is secluded and quiet. I need it to provide privacy
and a sense of my-ownness. Sounds pretty great, right? What about a big box to use as my space? It's secluded and it can be all my own. Solution-wise, it's a start, but a small one. We need to consider more options. What if I made adjustments to a
space I already have: my room? I could hang blankets from the ceiling
to help block out sounds from outside, and then I could also sing my
head off to T Swift if I wanted to without bothering the rest of my family. To top things off, I could add
a "Do Not Enter" sign to my door. Like, a serious sign. 
Bold font, all caps. Respect my sign! Okay, we've got two options. What else? What if instead of adjusting a space
I already have, I create a new space? There's a word for what we're
talking about here: architecture. Maybe we could become not just engineers,
but architects: engineers who design buildings. Even though the title of the job is a little
different, the process is still the same. So before doing architecture, we've got to weigh our options and choose
the best design to take into trials. Let's think about the box idea first. It's probably too small. I'd either be squished or
be half hanging out of it. Okay, how about tricking out my room? Again, while I'd feel like I have a sense
of privacy, I'd know that at any point, any one of my family members could bust in, and the blankets on the walls 
would muffle some of the sound, but wouldn't totally block them out. But hey, here's an idea:
what about a tree house? It would be totally my own, it would be far enough from my house that any weird burps or loud renditions
of "Shake It Off" wouldn't bug my family. Of course, it would take some
work. Some architecture work. So architect, activate!  [Music] Let's build the treehouse! It'll have a drop-down rope ladder that
I can pull up for optimal privacy, and it'll have windows so I can spot
when someone's on the way over and properly prepare myself. I can even use the blanket wall idea from
my second proposal to muffle the sound. Of course, I'll need space for lounging
and reading and dancing around, but before we start building,
you know what we've got to do? Build the prototype and test it. And in order to conduct useful trials,
we need to isolate the variables. What are the variables of
this particular mission? The size of the treehouse we choose
and the weight of the treehouse are really important variables
because we gotta make sure the treehouse can stay in the tree. What about variables when it comes
to soundproofing the thing? The number and the size of the
blankets that I use would be one, and so would be the amount of noise
I plan on making inside the treehouse. And we have to keep in
mind failure points, too. Like, the tree might be able to support
little old me in a small wooden tree house, but if I have a friend or two over,
the load might be too heavy. That would be a serious failure point. As for keeping things nice and quiet,
maybe my thickest heaviest blankets can block a soft rendition
of "You Belong With Me," but they might fail when I belt out
"Shake It Off" or have a burping contest. You've gotta test these things! So we'll keep working with the variables
until we've got a working design. Then, it's time to build. [Music] Architects use the same process,
the engineering process, when planning buildings from
skyscrapers to small family homes. I came up with what I think
will be a great treehouse, but as always, there can be lots
of different successful solutions. So here's your challenge: can you come
up with your own architecture solution? What would your building look like? How would it meet the success
criteria and navigate the variables? Let us know! [Music]

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: In the video, we see that one failure point is if she builds a treehouse, she may be able to stay in but can't have friends over. What is a failure point?
Options: A. A place where a solution to a problem fails., B. A place where a solution to a problem has limits., C. A place where a solution to a problem causes a collapse in the solution., D. A place where a solution to the problem causes another unknown variable.
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the main problem that the speaker wants to solve in the video? Options: A. They need a place to relax and have some space to themselves., B. They want to design a robot to rescue their phone from a storm drain., C. They want to build a treehouse for their family., D. They are designing a new product to sell online. Correct Option: A
Question 2: According to the video, what is one way to block out sounds from outside when creating a secluded space in a room? Options: A. By hanging blankets from the ceiling., B. By using a "Do Not Enter" sign., C. By playing music loudly., D. By turning off the lights. Correct Option: A
Question 3: What is the engineering process that the speaker mentions in the video? Options: A. It involves designing buildings and structures, considering variables and potential failure points, and testing and refining the design., B. It involves testing and trial-and-error methods., C. It involves analyzing data and statistics., D. It involves solving complex mathematical equations. Correct Option: A
Question 4: How does the speaker suggest using the engineering process to solve the problem of needing a secluded space? Options: A. By defining the problem, brainstorming solutions, testing and refining the design, and considering the variables and potential failure points., B. By building a prototype and ignoring the need for testing and refinement., C. By asking someone else to solve it for them., D. By ignoring the problem and doing something else. Correct Option: A
Question 5: What are some variables that the speaker mentions as being important to consider when designing the treehouse? Options: A. The size of the treehouse and the weight of the treehouse, the number and size of the blankets used for soundproofing, and the amount of noise made inside the treehouse., B. The color of the treehouse and the type of wood used., C. The location of the treehouse and the time of day it is used., D. The height of the treehouse and the number of windows. Correct Option: A
Question 6: What is one potential failure point that the speaker mentions when considering the weight capacity of the treehouse? Options: A. The tree might not be able to support the weight of the treehouse., B. The tree might be able to support the weight of the treehouse, but not the weight of the people inside it., C. The tree might be able to support the weight of the people inside the treehouse, but not the weight of the treehouse itself., D. The treehouse might not be able to support the weight of the people inside it, but the tree itself can support the weight of the treehouse. Correct Option: B
Question 7: How does the speaker suggest combining the ideas of adjusting a space they already have and creating a new space to solve the problem of needing a secluded space? Options: A. By using a combination of both ideas to create a unique solution, such as hanging blankets from the ceiling to block out sounds and creating a treehouse with a drop-down rope ladder., B. By choosing one idea over the other and sticking with no compromise., C. By ignoring one idea and only using the other., D. By asking someone else to decide which idea to use. Correct Option: A
Question 8: What is one benefit of using the engineering process to solve the problem of needing a secluded space? Options: A. It allows for a quick and easy solution., B. It provides a thorough and well-thought-out solution that considers the variables and potential failure points., C. It is a cost-effective solution., D. It is a solution that can be implemented immediately. Correct Option: B
Question 9: How does the speaker suggest testing and refining the design of the treehouse? Options: A. By building a prototype and conducting trials to isolate the variables and identify failure points, such as the weight capacity of the treehouse and the effectiveness of the soundproofing., B. By ignoring the need for testing and refinement., C. By asking someone else to test and refine the design., D. By only testing the design once before building it. Correct Option: A
Question 10: What is the main idea of the video, according to the speaker? Options: A. The video is about the importance of having a secluded space., B. The video is about the engineering process and how it can be used to solve problems, such as designing a treehouse that meets the success criteria and navigates the variables., C. The video is about the design of the treehouse and how it meets the success criteria., D. The video is about the importance of collaboration and teamwork. Correct Option: B

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 2, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
[Music] Hey there, engineer buddies! I just want to thank you so much
for helping out in the last episode. I needed to get my phone out of the storm
drain, and together, we designed a solution. Our robot was just one of many possible solutions, and maybe you had an even better idea at home. If you did, please send it my way.
I'd love to check it out! But I've got a whole new challenge for you. Have you ever just wanted
some space to yourself? A place to relax, do your own thing,
eat Nutella straight off your fingers, and burp with abandon? Yeah, I need that.
That is a thing I need. You know what can help? I bet you already guessed it! Engineering. So how do we use the engineering
process to solve this problem? [Music] Well, first, we've got to define the problem. I need a place that is secluded and quiet. I need it to provide privacy
and a sense of my-ownness. Sounds pretty great, right? What about a big box to use as my space? It's secluded and it can be all my own. Solution-wise, it's a start, but a small one. We need to consider more options. What if I made adjustments to a
space I already have: my room? I could hang blankets from the ceiling
to help block out sounds from outside, and then I could also sing my
head off to T Swift if I wanted to without bothering the rest of my family. To top things off, I could add
a "Do Not Enter" sign to my door. Like, a serious sign. 
Bold font, all caps. Respect my sign! Okay, we've got two options. What else? What if instead of adjusting a space
I already have, I create a new space? There's a word for what we're
talking about here: architecture. Maybe we could become not just engineers,
but architects: engineers who design buildings. Even though the title of the job is a little
different, the process is still the same. So before doing architecture, we've got to weigh our options and choose
the best design to take into trials. Let's think about the box idea first. It's probably too small. I'd either be squished or
be half hanging out of it. Okay, how about tricking out my room? Again, while I'd feel like I have a sense
of privacy, I'd know that at any point, any one of my family members could bust in, and the blankets on the walls 
would muffle some of the sound, but wouldn't totally block them out. But hey, here's an idea:
what about a tree house? It would be totally my own, it would be far enough from my house that any weird burps or loud renditions
of "Shake It Off" wouldn't bug my family. Of course, it would take some
work. Some architecture work. So architect, activate!  [Music] Let's build the treehouse! It'll have a drop-down rope ladder that
I can pull up for optimal privacy, and it'll have windows so I can spot
when someone's on the way over and properly prepare myself. I can even use the blanket wall idea from
my second proposal to muffle the sound. Of course, I'll need space for lounging
and reading and dancing around, but before we start building,
you know what we've got to do? Build the prototype and test it. And in order to conduct useful trials,
we need to isolate the variables. What are the variables of
this particular mission? The size of the treehouse we choose
and the weight of the treehouse are really important variables
because we gotta make sure the treehouse can stay in the tree. What about variables when it comes
to soundproofing the thing? The number and the size of the
blankets that I use would be one, and so would be the amount of noise
I plan on making inside the treehouse. And we have to keep in
mind failure points, too. Like, the tree might be able to support
little old me in a small wooden tree house, but if I have a friend or two over,
the load might be too heavy. That would be a serious failure point. As for keeping things nice and quiet,
maybe my thickest heaviest blankets can block a soft rendition
of "You Belong With Me," but they might fail when I belt out
"Shake It Off" or have a burping contest. You've gotta test these things! So we'll keep working with the variables
until we've got a working design. Then, it's time to build. [Music] Architects use the same process,
the engineering process, when planning buildings from
skyscrapers to small family homes. I came up with what I think
will be a great treehouse, but as always, there can be lots
of different successful solutions. So here's your challenge: can you come
up with your own architecture solution? What would your building look like? How would it meet the success
criteria and navigate the variables? Let us know! [Music]

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: In order to be successful, we need to isolate variables (elements or factors that are important or can change an idea). Why is it important that we look at the size of the tree and the weight of the treehouse?
Options: A. We need to make sure we won't kill the tree., B. We need to make sure that we make a treehouse that looks pretty with the tree., C. We need to make sure that the tree house will be stable., D. We need to make sure that the treehouse stays private.
Correct Option: C

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What is the main problem that the speaker wants to solve in the video? Options: A. They need a place to relax and have some space to themselves., B. They want to design a robot to rescue their phone from a storm drain., C. They want to build a treehouse for their family., D. They are designing a new product to sell online. Correct Option: A
Question 2: According to the video, what is one way to block out sounds from outside when creating a secluded space in a room? Options: A. By hanging blankets from the ceiling., B. By using a "Do Not Enter" sign., C. By playing music loudly., D. By turning off the lights. Correct Option: A
Question 3: What is the engineering process that the speaker mentions in the video? Options: A. It involves designing buildings and structures, considering variables and potential failure points, and testing and refining the design., B. It involves testing and trial-and-error methods., C. It involves analyzing data and statistics., D. It involves solving complex mathematical equations. Correct Option: A
Question 4: How does the speaker suggest using the engineering process to solve the problem of needing a secluded space? Options: A. By defining the problem, brainstorming solutions, testing and refining the design, and considering the variables and potential failure points., B. By building a prototype and ignoring the need for testing and refinement., C. By asking someone else to solve it for them., D. By ignoring the problem and doing something else. Correct Option: A
Question 5: What are some variables that the speaker mentions as being important to consider when designing the treehouse? Options: A. The size of the treehouse and the weight of the treehouse, the number and size of the blankets used for soundproofing, and the amount of noise made inside the treehouse., B. The color of the treehouse and the type of wood used., C. The location of the treehouse and the time of day it is used., D. The height of the treehouse and the number of windows. Correct Option: A
Question 6: What is one potential failure point that the speaker mentions when considering the weight capacity of the treehouse? Options: A. The tree might not be able to support the weight of the treehouse., B. The tree might be able to support the weight of the treehouse, but not the weight of the people inside it., C. The tree might be able to support the weight of the people inside the treehouse, but not the weight of the treehouse itself., D. The treehouse might not be able to support the weight of the people inside it, but the tree itself can support the weight of the treehouse. Correct Option: B
Question 7: How does the speaker suggest combining the ideas of adjusting a space they already have and creating a new space to solve the problem of needing a secluded space? Options: A. By using a combination of both ideas to create a unique solution, such as hanging blankets from the ceiling to block out sounds and creating a treehouse with a drop-down rope ladder., B. By choosing one idea over the other and sticking with no compromise., C. By ignoring one idea and only using the other., D. By asking someone else to decide which idea to use. Correct Option: A
Question 8: What is one benefit of using the engineering process to solve the problem of needing a secluded space? Options: A. It allows for a quick and easy solution., B. It provides a thorough and well-thought-out solution that considers the variables and potential failure points., C. It is a cost-effective solution., D. It is a solution that can be implemented immediately. Correct Option: B
Question 9: How does the speaker suggest testing and refining the design of the treehouse? Options: A. By building a prototype and conducting trials to isolate the variables and identify failure points, such as the weight capacity of the treehouse and the effectiveness of the soundproofing., B. By ignoring the need for testing and refinement., C. By asking someone else to test and refine the design., D. By only testing the design once before building it. Correct Option: A
Question 10: What is the main idea of the video, according to the speaker? Options: A. The video is about the importance of having a secluded space., B. The video is about the engineering process and how it can be used to solve problems, such as designing a treehouse that meets the success criteria and navigates the variables., C. The video is about the design of the treehouse and how it meets the success criteria., D. The video is about the importance of collaboration and teamwork. Correct Option: B


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 5. 

However, the question intent is not an exact match. Question 5 asks about the variables that are important to consider when designing the treehouse, while the ground truth MCQ asks why it is important to look at the size of the tree and the weight of the treehouse.

A more similar question is Question 6, which asks about a potential failure point when considering the weight capacity of the treehouse. This question is more closely related to the ground truth MCQ, as it deals with the importance of considering the weight of the treehouse.

But the most similar question is actually Question 9's option A, which mentions "the weight capacity of the treehouse" as a variable to be tested and refined.

However, if I had to choose one of the questions as it is, I would say that Question 6 is the most similar.

So, the index of the most similar generated MCQ is: 6.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 3, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Hey, today we are going to have fun with learning
about Black History and a man named Malcolm X. With Black History in the United States, many
African-Americans mention Malcolm X. Do you know who Malcolm X is? Malcolm X was an African-American Civil Rights
Activist and Minister. Right now we will learn a little bit about
his life. Malcolm X was born Malcolm Little on May 19,
1925 in Omaha, Nebraska. Malcolm was the fourth of eight children born
to Louise, a homemaker, and Earl Little, a preacher. His father spoke out against racism and was
often picked on by a group named the Ku Klux Klan. It was so bad the littles had to move from
Omaha and his father was later found murdered. After the death of Malcolm’s father, Malcolm's
mother became very sick and could not take care of her children. This is where Malcolm and his siblings were
placed in foster care. Seeing all of this Malcolm would get into
trouble later on finding himself in a juvenile detention center, and later on finding himself
in prison after getting in trouble. It was there his life would change when he
discovered a religion known as Islam. After choosing the religion of Islam and joining
the Nation of Islam, Malcolm Little would soon change his name from to Malcolm X, where
he would go on to be a well-known leader of the Nation of Islam. During this time another African-American
Civil Rights Activist was Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. Although Dr. King spoke about peaceful protests,
Malcolm X was known for saying, “By any means necessary,” and "You don't have to
have a peaceful revolution," when speaking against racism. Malcolm X would later leave the Nation of
Islam and become a traditional Muslim where he changed his name to El-Hajj Malik El-Shabazz. Malcolm X’s life came to an end after he
was assassinated on February 21, 1965, in New York, New York. That is all for me and I hope you enjoyed
learning about Black History and Malcolm X a civil rights activist and preacher. I hope you had fun learning with F.R.E.S.B.E.R.G
cartoon.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: While Martin Luther King Jr. and Malcolm X approached the Civil Rights Movement differently, they did have two things in common. What were they?
Options: A. They were both ministers and they both grew up in Nebraska., B. They were both ministers and they were both assassinated., C. They were both assassinated and they both found religion as adults., D. Both had sick mothers who died and fathers that were ministers.
Correct Option: B

**Generated MCQs**:
Question 1: What was the name of Malcolm X's father? Options: A. Earl Little, B. Malcolm Little, C. Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr., D. Malcolm X Correct Option: A
Question 2: What was the name of the group that often picked on Malcolm X's father? Options: A. The Nation of Islam, B. The Ku Klux Klan, C. F.R.E.S.B.E.R.G, D. African-American Civil Rights Activists Correct Option: B
Question 3: Why did Malcolm X and his siblings have to move from Omaha? Options: A. Because of his father's job, B. Because of his father's murder, C. Because of his mother's illness, D. Because of the Nation of Islam Correct Option: B
Question 4: What was Malcolm X's name before he joined the Nation of Islam? Options: A. Malcolm X, B. El-Hajj Malik El-Shabazz, C. Malcolm Little, D. Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. Correct Option: C
Question 5: What was the name of the religion that Malcolm X discovered in prison? Options: A. Islam, B. Christianity, C. Judaism, D. Hinduism Correct Option: A
Question 6: Why did Malcolm X leave the Nation of Islam? Options: A. Because he disagreed with the Nation of Islam's views, B. Because he wanted to become a traditional Muslim, C. Because he wanted to become a preacher, D. Because he wanted to join the Ku Klux Klan Correct Option: B
Question 7: What was the main difference between Malcolm X's views and Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr.'s views? Options: A. Malcolm X believed in peaceful protests, while Dr. King believed in violent protests, B. Malcolm X believed in peaceful protests, while Dr. King believed in non-violent protests, C. Malcolm X believed in violent protests, while Dr. King believed in peaceful protests, D. Malcolm X believed in non-violent protests, while Dr. King believed in violent protests Correct Option: C
Question 8: What was the name of the cartoon that was used to teach about Malcolm X? Options: A. F.R.E.S.B.E.R.G, B. Nation of Islam, C. Ku Klux Klan, D. Malcolm X Correct Option: A
Question 9: Why was Malcolm X assassinated? Options: A. Because of his views on racism, B. Because of his views on peaceful protests, C. Because of his views on violent protests, D. Because of his views on non-violent protests Correct Option: A
Question 10: What was the significance of Malcolm X's life? Options: A. He was a well-known leader of the Nation of Islam, B. He was a traditional Muslim, C. He was a civil rights activist and preacher, D. All of the above Correct Option: D


Please identify the generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ, based on question intent, options, and content.
Provide the index of the most similar generated MCQ.

Matching Response:
After analyzing the ground truth MCQ and the generated MCQs, I found that the most similar generated MCQ is Question 7. A more suitable match is not available among the provided generated MCQs, as none of them directly address the commonalities between Malcolm X and Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr.

However, if I had to choose the most similar generated MCQ based on the content and intent, I would choose Question 7, with the understanding that it does not perfectly match the ground truth MCQ.

Index of the most similar generated MCQ: 7

Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Hey, today we are going to have fun with learning
about Black History and a man named Malcolm X. With Black History in the United States, many
African-Americans mention Malcolm X. Do you know who Malcolm X is? Malcolm X was an African-American Civil Rights
Activist and Minister. Right now we will learn a little bit about
his life. Malcolm X was born Malcolm Little on May 19,
1925 in Omaha, Nebraska. Malcolm was the fourth of eight children born
to Louise, a homemaker, and Earl Little, a preacher. His father spoke out against racism and was
often picked on by a group named the Ku Klux Klan. It was so bad the littles had to move from
Omaha and his father was later found murdered. After the death of Malcolm’s father, Malcolm's
mother became very sick and could not take care of her children. This is where Malcolm and his siblings were
placed in foster care. Seeing all of this Malcolm would get into
trouble later on finding himself in a juvenile detention center, and later on finding himself
in prison after getting in trouble. It was there his life would change when he
discovered a religion known as Islam. After choosing the religion of Islam and joining
the Nation of Islam, Malcolm Little would soon change his name from to Malcolm X, where
he would go on to be a well-known leader of the Nation of Islam. During this time another African-American
Civil Rights Activist was Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. Although Dr. King spoke about peaceful protests,
Malcolm X was known for saying, “By any means necessary,” and "You don't have to
have a peaceful revolution," when speaking against racism. Malcolm X would later leave the Nation of
Islam and become a traditional Muslim where he changed his name to El-Hajj Malik El-Shabazz. Malcolm X’s life came to an end after he
was assassinated on February 21, 1965, in New York, New York. That is all for me and I hope you enjoyed
learning about Black History and Malcolm X a civil rights activist and preacher. I hope you had fun learning with F.R.E.S.B.E.R.G
cartoon.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 3, Question 3
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Hey, today we are going to have fun with learning
about Black History and a man named Malcolm X. With Black History in the United States, many
African-Americans mention Malcolm X. Do you know who Malcolm X is? Malcolm X was an African-American Civil Rights
Activist and Minister. Right now we will learn a little bit about
his life. Malcolm X was born Malcolm Little on May 19,
1925 in Omaha, Nebraska. Malcolm was the fourth of eight children born
to Louise, a homemaker, and Earl Little, a preacher. His father spoke out against racism and was
often picked on by a group named the Ku Klux Klan. It was so bad the littles had to move from
Omaha and his father was later found murdered. After the death of Malcolm’s father, Malcolm's
mother became very sick and could not take care of her children. This is where Malcolm and his siblings were
placed in foster care. Seeing all of this Malcolm would get into
trouble later on finding himself in a juvenile detention center, and later on finding himself
in prison after getting in trouble. It was there his life would change when he
discovered a religion known as Islam. After choosing the religion of Islam and joining
the Nation of Islam, Malcolm Little would soon change his name from to Malcolm X, where
he would go on to be a well-known leader of the Nation of Islam. During this time another African-American
Civil Rights Activist was Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. Although Dr. King spoke about peaceful protests,
Malcolm X was known for saying, “By any means necessary,” and "You don't have to
have a peaceful revolution," when speaking against racism. Malcolm X would later leave the Nation of
Islam and become a traditional Muslim where he changed his name to El-Hajj Malik El-Shabazz. Malcolm X’s life came to an end after he
was assassinated on February 21, 1965, in New York, New York. That is all for me and I hope you enjoyed
learning about Black History and Malcolm X a civil rights activist and preacher. I hope you had fun learning with F.R.E.S.B.E.R.G
cartoon.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: Why was Malcolm's family forced to move from Omaha, Nebraska?
Options: A. They were being attacked by the Ku Klux Klan., B. His father received an important job elsewhere., C. His mother became ill and they moved to be closer to a hospital., D. They didn't have enough money to stay in Omaha.
Correct Option: A

Question 4: What was Malcolm X's name before he joined the Nation of Islam? Options: A. Malcolm X, B. El-Hajj Malik El-Shabazz, C. Malcolm Little, D. Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. Correct Option: C
Question 5: What was the name of the religion that Malcolm X discovered in prison? Options: A. Islam, B. Christianity, C. Judaism, D. Hinduism Correct Option: A
Question 6: Why did Malcolm X leave the Nation of Islam? Options: A. Because he disagreed with the Nation of Islam's views, B. Because he wanted to become a traditional Muslim, C. Because he wanted to become a preacher, D. Because he wanted to join the Ku Klux Klan Correct Option: B
Question 7: What was the main difference between Malcolm X's views and Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr.'s views? Options: A. Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 3, Question 4
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
Hey, today we are going to have fun with learning
about Black History and a man named Malcolm X. With Black History in the United States, many
African-Americans mention Malcolm X. Do you know who Malcolm X is? Malcolm X was an African-American Civil Rights
Activist and Minister. Right now we will learn a little bit about
his life. Malcolm X was born Malcolm Little on May 19,
1925 in Omaha, Nebraska. Malcolm was the fourth of eight children born
to Louise, a homemaker, and Earl Little, a preacher. His father spoke out against racism and was
often picked on by a group named the Ku Klux Klan. It was so bad the littles had to move from
Omaha and his father was later found murdered. After the death of Malcolm’s father, Malcolm's
mother became very sick and could not take care of her children. This is where Malcolm and his siblings were
placed in foster care. Seeing all of this Malcolm would get into
trouble later on finding himself in a juvenile detention center, and later on finding himself
in prison after getting in trouble. It was there his life would change when he
discovered a religion known as Islam. After choosing the religion of Islam and joining
the Nation of Islam, Malcolm Little would soon change his name from to Malcolm X, where
he would go on to be a well-known leader of the Nation of Islam. During this time another African-American
Civil Rights Activist was Dr. Martin Luther King, Jr. Although Dr. King spoke about peaceful protests,
Malcolm X was known for saying, “By any means necessary,” and "You don't have to
have a peaceful revolution," when speaking against racism. Malcolm X would later leave the Nation of
Islam and become a traditional Muslim where he changed his name to El-Hajj Malik El-Shabazz. Malcolm X’s life came to an end after he
was assassinated on February 21, 1965, in New York, New York. That is all for me and I hope you enjoyed
learning about Black History and Malcolm X a civil rights activist and preacher. I hope you had fun learning with F.R.E.S.B.E.R.G
cartoon.

Matching Response:
The generated MCQ that most closely matches the ground truth MCQ is Question 3. 

Although Question 3 does not directly mention the KKK, its content is closely related to the event described in the ground truth MCQ. The ground truth MCQ asks about the KKK causing another major event in Malcolm's life, which is the killing of his father and the subsequent need for the family to move. Question 3 asks why Malcolm X and his siblings had to move from Omaha, and the correct answer is "Because of his father's murder," which is a direct consequence of the KKK's actions.

However, it's worth noting that there isn't a perfect match among the generated MCQs, as none of them directly mention the KKK as the cause of the event. But Question 3 is the closest match in terms of content and intent.

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 4, Question 1
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
The evil wizard MoldeVort 
has been trying to kill you for years, and today it looks like 
he’s going to succeed. But your friends are on their way, 
and if you can survive until they arrive, they should be able to help stop him. The evil wizard’s protective charms 
ward off every spell you know, so in an act of desperation 
you throw the only object in reach at him: Pythagoras’s cursed chessboard. It works, but with a catch. MoldeVort starts in one corner 
of the 5x5 board. You have a few minutes to choose 
four distinct positive whole numbers. MoldeVort gets to say one of them, 
and if you can pick a square on the board whose center is exactly 
that distance away, the curse will force him 
to move to that spot. Then he’ll have to choose 
any of the four numbers, and the process repeats until 
you can’t keep him inside the board with legal moves. Then he’ll break free of the spell 
and almost certainly kill you. What four numbers can you choose 
to keep MoldeVort trapped by your spell long enough for help to arrive? 
And what’s your strategy? Pause the video to figure it out yourself. Answer in 3 Answer in 2 Answer in 1 The trick here is to keep MoldeVort 
where you want him. And one way to figure out how to do that is to play out the game 
as MoldeVort would: always trying to escape. You’re dealing with a relatively 
small board, so the numbers can’t be too big. Let’s start by trying 1, 2, 3, 4 
to see what happens. Moldevort could escape those numbers
in just three moves. By saying 2, then 3, he would force you to let him into one
of the middle points of the grid, and then a 4 would break him free. But that means you’ll need to allow
a number larger than 4, which is the distance from one end 
of a row to another. How is that even possible? Through diagonal moves. There are, in fact, points that are 
distance 5 from each other, which we know thanks 
to the Pythagorean Theorem. That states that the squares 
of the sides of a right triangle add up to the square of its hypotenuse. One of the most famous 
Pythagorean triples is 3, 4, 5, and that triangle is hiding all over 
your chessboard. So if MoldeVort was here, and he said 5,
you could move him to these spaces. There’s another insight that will help. The board is very symmetrical: 
If MoldeVort is in a corner, it doesn’t really matter 
to you which corner it is. So we can think of the corners 
as being functionally the same, and color them all blue. Similarly, the spaces neighboring 
the corners behave the same as each other, and we’ll make them red. Finally, the midpoints of the sides 
are a third type. So instead of having to develop a strategy for each of the 16 spaces 
on the outside of the board, we can reduce the problem to just three. Meanwhile, all the inside spaces 
are bad for us, because if MoldeVort ever reaches one, he’ll be able to say any number 
larger than 3 and go free. Orange spaces are trouble too, 
since any number except 1, 2, or 4 would take him to an inside space 
or off the board. So orange is out and you’ll need 
to keep him on blue and red. That means 2 is bad, since it could take MoldeVort 
to orange on the first turn. But the four other smallest numbers, 
1, 3, 4, and 5, might work. Let’s try them and see what happens. If MoldeVort says 1, you can make 
him go from blue to red or red to blue. And the same works if he says 3. Thanks to our diagonals, 
this is even true if he says 5. If he says 4, you can keep him 
on the color he’s already on by moving the length of a row or column. So these four numbers work! Even if your friends don’t get here 
right away, you’ll be able to keep 
the world’s most evil wizard contained for as long as you need.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: What are the dimensions of the cursed chessboard?
Options: A. 4 by 4, B. 5 by 5, C. 6 by 6, D. 8 by 8
Correct Option: B

It helps the protagonist calculate the distance between spaces, D. It is irrelevant to the situation Correct Option: C

Blue spaces are good, red spaces are bad, and orange spaces are neutral, C. Blue spaces are functionally the same, red spaces behave the same as each other, and the midpoints of the sides are a third type, D. The spaces are randomly assigned to each color Correct Option: C

It keeps the evil wizard on the color he's already on, C. It forces the evil wizard to move to an inside space, D. It has no advantage Correct Option: B

It helps the protagonist simplify the problem by considering the corners as functionally the same, D. It is irrelevant to the situation Correct Option: C

Match Phase - Ground Truth Set 4, Question 2
Matching Prompt:

You are an expert evaluator for educational content. Given a transcript and a set of ground truth multiple-choice questions (MCQs), your task is to match each ground truth MCQ with the most similar generated MCQ from the provided set. To determine similarity, consider the question content, options, and overall intent.

**Transcript**:
The evil wizard MoldeVort 
has been trying to kill you for years, and today it looks like 
he’s going to succeed. But your friends are on their way, 
and if you can survive until they arrive, they should be able to help stop him. The evil wizard’s protective charms 
ward off every spell you know, so in an act of desperation 
you throw the only object in reach at him: Pythagoras’s cursed chessboard. It works, but with a catch. MoldeVort starts in one corner 
of the 5x5 board. You have a few minutes to choose 
four distinct positive whole numbers. MoldeVort gets to say one of them, 
and if you can pick a square on the board whose center is exactly 
that distance away, the curse will force him 
to move to that spot. Then he’ll have to choose 
any of the four numbers, and the process repeats until 
you can’t keep him inside the board with legal moves. Then he’ll break free of the spell 
and almost certainly kill you. What four numbers can you choose 
to keep MoldeVort trapped by your spell long enough for help to arrive? 
And what’s your strategy? Pause the video to figure it out yourself. Answer in 3 Answer in 2 Answer in 1 The trick here is to keep MoldeVort 
where you want him. And one way to figure out how to do that is to play out the game 
as MoldeVort would: always trying to escape. You’re dealing with a relatively 
small board, so the numbers can’t be too big. Let’s start by trying 1, 2, 3, 4 
to see what happens. Moldevort could escape those numbers
in just three moves. By saying 2, then 3, he would force you to let him into one
of the middle points of the grid, and then a 4 would break him free. But that means you’ll need to allow
a number larger than 4, which is the distance from one end 
of a row to another. How is that even possible? Through diagonal moves. There are, in fact, points that are 
distance 5 from each other, which we know thanks 
to the Pythagorean Theorem. That states that the squares 
of the sides of a right triangle add up to the square of its hypotenuse. One of the most famous 
Pythagorean triples is 3, 4, 5, and that triangle is hiding all over 
your chessboard. So if MoldeVort was here, and he said 5,
you could move him to these spaces. There’s another insight that will help. The board is very symmetrical: 
If MoldeVort is in a corner, it doesn’t really matter 
to you which corner it is. So we can think of the corners 
as being functionally the same, and color them all blue. Similarly, the spaces neighboring 
the corners behave the same as each other, and we’ll make them red. Finally, the midpoints of the sides 
are a third type. So instead of having to develop a strategy for each of the 16 spaces 
on the outside of the board, we can reduce the problem to just three. Meanwhile, all the inside spaces 
are bad for us, because if MoldeVort ever reaches one, he’ll be able to say any number 
larger than 3 and go free. Orange spaces are trouble too, 
since any number except 1, 2, or 4 would take him to an inside space 
or off the board. So orange is out and you’ll need 
to keep him on blue and red. That means 2 is bad, since it could take MoldeVort 
to orange on the first turn. But the four other smallest numbers, 
1, 3, 4, and 5, might work. Let’s try them and see what happens. If MoldeVort says 1, you can make 
him go from blue to red or red to blue. And the same works if he says 3. Thanks to our diagonals, 
this is even true if he says 5. If he says 4, you can keep him 
on the color he’s already on by moving the length of a row or column. So these four numbers work! Even if your friends don’t get here 
right away, you’ll be able to keep 
the world’s most evil wizard contained for as long as you need.

**Ground Truth MCQ**:

Options: A. 2, B. 3, C. 4, D. 5
Correct Option: C

**Ground Truth MCQ**:
Question: How can MoldeVort get free?
Options: A. If he can overpower the spell with magical strength., B. If he can’t make a legal move without going off the board or off the center of a square., C. If he finds the enchanted chess pieces., D. If he can reverse the spell using a symmetry spell.
Correct Option: B
